grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to indicate that the preceding event and the following one happened sequentially.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 지수는 친구에게 화분을 하나 얻어서 키우기 시작했다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Jisoo got a flowerpot from her friend and started growing it.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A connective ending used for a reason or cause.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 지수는 시간이 없어서 식사도 못 했다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Jisoo couldn't even eat because she didn't have time.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to emphasize that the preceding statement is the cause, reason, or premise for the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 학교에 가야 되니까 지금 못 만나요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I need to go to school, so I won’t be able to meet
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 옆방이 아주 시끄러우니까 저는 잠을 못 잤어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The room next to us is very loud, so I couldn’t sleep

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to express the purpose of an action such as going and coming.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 갑자기 친구들이 집에 놀러 왔다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Suddenly, my friends came to my house to hang out.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 어머니는 과일을 사러 잠깐 시장에 가셨다
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: My mother went to the market to buy some fruit

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one has the intention or wish to do the act mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 내일부터는 일찍 일어나려고 한다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I try to get up early from tomorrow.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to indicate that the incident mentioned in the preceding statement is likely to happen or begin soon.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 비가 오려고 하는지 구름이 잔뜩 끼었다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: It was cloudy as if it was about to rain.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when more than two actions or states happen at the same time.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 저는 밥을 먹으면서 공부했어요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I ate (rice) while studying
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 저는 영화를 보면서 콜라를 마셨어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I drank cola while watching a movie

grammar.gramInDepth1: To indicate that one action occurs “when or if” another action (that hasn’t happened yet) occurs
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 집에 일찍 도착하면 빨래를 할 거예요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: If I arrive home early, I will do laundry
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 내일 비바람이 오면 경기가 취소될 거예요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: If it storms tomorrow, the match(game) will be cancelled

grammar.gramInDepth1: A sentence-final ending used when the speaker confirms and says something that the listener thought he or she already knew.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 오늘 본 영화는 좀 지루했죠.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: The movie I watched today was a bit boring.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A sentence-final ending used to ask something that the speaker already knows to cross-check the information.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 오늘 날씨가 참 좋죠?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Lovely day today, isn't it?

grammar.gramInDepth1: A sentence-final ending used to indicate a question or assumption about something.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 저 사람이 지수 동생일까?
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Is that Jisoo's sister?
grammar.gramInDepth2: A sentence-final ending used to ask for the listener's opinion.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 우리 같이 저녁 먹으러 갈까?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Shall we go to dinner together?

grammar.gramInDepth1: A sentence-final ending used to indicate the speaker's intention to do something in the future, or to ask for the listener's thoughts about that.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 오늘은 피곤해서 일찍 잘래.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I'm tired today, so I'm going to bed early.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 내일 산에 갈 때 몇 시에 출발할래요?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: What time do you want to leave when you go to the mountain tomorrow?

grammar.gramInDepth1: (formal) A sentence-final ending used to express an intention of doing a certain action together.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 늦었으니 빨리 갑시다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: It's late, so let's go quickly.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 그 규정을 내일부터 시행합시다
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Let’s enforce that rule starting tomorrow

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used when the speaker promises or notifies the listener that he orshe will do something.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 지금 밥을 먹을게요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I will eat now
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 지금 주문할게요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I will order now

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that a certain act is allowed or accepted.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 박물관 안에서 사진을 찍어도 될지 물어 보자.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Let's ask if we can take a picture inside the museum.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 화장실에 가도 돼요?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: May I go to the bathroom?

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to decide or promise the performance of the act mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 제가 친구를 공원에서 만나기로 했어요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I decided to meet my friend in the park
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 내일 친구랑 음악회에 같이 가기로 했어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I decided to go to the concert with my friend tomorrow

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the act or state mentioned in the preceding statement existed at some point in time.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 그 사람을 만난 적이 있어요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I’ve met him once.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 일본에 가 본 적이 있습니까?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Have you ever been to Japan?

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the act or state mentioned in the preceding statement never existed.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 나는 스페인에 가 본 적이 없다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I’ve never been to Spain.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 나는 그런 생각을 해 본 적이 없다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The thought never entered my head.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to talk in advance about a situation to follow.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 식사 시간이 되었는데 괜찮다면 같이 밥 먹을래?
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: It's meal time, so would you like to eat with me if you don't mind?
grammar.gramInDepth2: (informal addressee-lowering) A sentence-final ending used to admire something while anticipating the listener's response.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 그 옷이 너한테 아주 잘 어울리는데.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: That dress looks very good on you.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the speaker has an intention to do the act mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 몸도 좋지 않으니 오늘은 아무 데도 안 나가고 집에서 좀 쉴까 봐요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I'm not feeling well either, so I think I'll go out and rest at home today.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 아이는 소풍 가는 날에 비가 올까 봐 벌써부터 걱정을 한다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The child is already worried about rain on the picnic day.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate the duration, period, or occasion of a certain act or situation.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 해외로 여행을 갈 때 여권은 반드시 챙겨야 한다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: When you travel abroad, you must bring your passport.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to indicate that the speaker is worried or afraid that the situation mentioned in the preceding statement may happen.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 나는 운동할 때 꼭 음악을 듣는다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I always listen to music when I exercise.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to state that a certain act occurs earlier than the act in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 밥 먹기 전에 손부터 씻어라.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Wash your hands before you eat.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 저녁 먹기 전에 잠깐 가서 좀 씻고 올게요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I’ll just go and freshen up before supper.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A conjunctive adverb used when the following statement is conditional upon the preceding one.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 어머니께 말하는 게 어때? 그러면 해결책이 생길 거야.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Why don't you tell your mother? Then there will be a solution.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A conjunction used when accepting the preceding statement or building on it to make a new claim.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 준비가 끝났나요? 그러면 이제 출발하겠습니다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Are you ready? Let's go now.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that something is for the benefit of someone or for a goal or purpose.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 저는 회사를 위해 열심히 일할 거예요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I will work hard for the company
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 군인은 나라를 위해서 일하는 사람입니다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Soliders are people who work for their country.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A postpositional particle that means "except for that" or "other than that."
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 우리가 먹을 것은 밥밖에 없어요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: We have nothing but rice to eat
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 그거를 사고 싶지만 만 원밖에 없어서 못 사요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I want to buy that, but I only have 10,000 won, so I can’t buy it

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the time being described takes places after the completion of a certain work or process mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 승규는 대학을 졸업한 다음에 군대에 갔다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Seung-gyu went to the army after graduating from college.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 외국어를 공부할 때는 발음을 잘 들은 다음에 따라 하는 것이 중요하다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: When studying a foreign language, it is important to listen to the pronunciation carefully and follow it.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when assuming or recognizing the truth of the preceding statement, but implying that it is not related to or does not influence the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 그랑 일대일로 면담하려고 해 봐도 그는 말을 안 할 거예요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Regardless of if you try to talk with him (face to face) he won’t say anything
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 달콤한 치킨을 안 좋아해도 이것을 한번 먹어 봐야 돼요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Regardless of if you don’t like sweet chicken, you have to try this

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to recognize the truth of the preceding statement and add facts that are the opposite of it or different.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 승규는 머리는 좋지만 다소 산만하다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Seung-gyu is smart but somewhat distracted.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 서울은 가 봤지만 제주도는 못 가 봤어요.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I've been to Seoul, but I haven't been to Jeju Island.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to indicate that the following event or situation occurs right after the preceding event or situation.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 나는 너무 피곤해서 침대에 눕자마자 잠이 들었다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I was so tired that I fell asleep as soon as I lay on the bed.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 민준이는 게임을 좋아해서 집에 오자마자 항상 컴퓨터부터 켠다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Minjun likes to play games, so he always turns on the computer as soon as he gets home.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to check with or correct the listener on something about a certain situation.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 목요일에는 영어 회화 수업이 있잖아요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: We have an English conversation class on Thursday.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 맞잖아요!
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I told you it was correct!

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one does a certain act mentioned in the preceding statement and a while later, does another thing.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 승규는 보통 식사를 마친 후에 커피를 마신다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Seung-gyu usually drinks coffee after finishing his meal.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 밥을 먹은 후에 이 약을 좀 먹어 보세요.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Please take some of this medicine after you eat.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one does know a certain fact or state.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 내가 기다릴 줄 알았니? 몰랐니?
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Did you think I'd wait? Didn't you know?
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to indicate that one knows how to do a certain thing.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 승규는 일본어를 할 줄 안다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Seung-gyu knows how to speak Japanese.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one does not know a certain fact or state.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 여기에서 선생님을 만날 줄 몰랐어요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I didn't expect to see you here.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to indicate that one does not know how to do a certain thing.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 우리 아이는 아직 글을 쓸 줄 몰라요.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: My child can't write yet.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one cannot do something.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 저도 그것을 할 수 있어요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I can do that too
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 살이 많이 빠져서 지금 정장을 편히 입을 수 있어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I can solve this math question without any issue

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one cannot do something.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 제가 너무 아파서 많이 먹을 수 없어요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I can’t eat much because I am very sick
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 저는 그 사실을 믿을 수 없어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I can wear a suit comfortably now because I lost a lot of weight

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the time being described takes places after the completion of a certain work or process mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 승규는 대학을 졸업한 다음에 군대에 갔다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Seung-gyu went to the army after graduating from college.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 전자 제품을 살 때에는 가격과 성능을 꼼꼼히 비교해 본 다음에 사야 한다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: When buying electronics, you should carefully compare prices and performance before buying them.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one does the act mentioned in the preceding statement, as a test.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 지수는 파마머리를 시도해 보고 싶어 미용실에 갔다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Ji-Soo went to the hair salon because she wanted to try perm hair.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to indicate that one experienced the act mentioned in the preceding statement earlier.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 나는 언어학 전공이지만 물리에도 관심이 많아 물리 공부도 많이 해 봤다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I majored in linguistics, but I am also interested in physics, so I have studied physics a lot.

grammar.gramInDepth1: (informal addressee-raising) An expression used to indicate the speaker's reasoning or the basis for the preceding content.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 오늘은 지각하면 안 돼요. 오늘 수업에서 제가 발표를 하거든요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: You can't be late today. I'm going to give a presentation in today's class.
grammar.gramInDepth2: (informal addressee-raising) An expression used to express the premise of the following content, indicating that the story continues later.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 제가 자료를 좀 찾아 봤거든요. 그런데 찾기가 쉽지 않더라고요.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I looked up some data. But it's not easy to find.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to express that the incident mentioned in the preceding statement almost occurred but ultimately did not occur.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 급하게 뛰어오다가 하마터면 넘어질 뻔했다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I almost fell while running in a hurry.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 조금만 더 늦었더라면 기차를 놓칠 뻔했다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: If I had been a little late, I would have missed the train.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that there is no other method or possibility other than that.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 공부를 안 하면 시험에 떨어질 수밖에 없다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: If you don't study, you'll have to fail the exam.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 열쇠가 없어서 어머니가 오실 때까지 밖에서 기다릴 수밖에 없었다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: There was no key, so I had to wait outside until my mother came.

grammar.gramInDepth1: (informal addressee-raising) An expression used to indicate that the content of the preceding statement is the speaker's opinion or guess.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 지수는 아직 학교에 다닐걸요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Jisoo probably still goes to school.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 잠시 후면 그 사람들도 이쪽으로 올걸요.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: They'll be here in a minute.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate the speaker's strong guess about the preceding statement and add the relevant content.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 집에 어머니가 계실 텐데 왜 전화를 안 받지?
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Why isn't my mother answering the phone when she's home?
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 지금까지 아무것도 못 먹어서 배가 많이 고플 텐데 많이 먹어.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: You must be hungry because you haven't eaten anything so far, so eat a lot.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to list more than two actions, states, or facts.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 우리는 함께 여행도 다니고 전화와 편지도 주고받으며 조금씩 가까워졌다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: We traveled together, exchanged phone calls and letters, and got closer little by little.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A connective ending used when more than two actions or states happen at the same time.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 지수는 친구들에게 웃으며 인사했다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Ji-Soo greeted her friends with a smile.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when one of either the preceding statement or the following statement can be chosen.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 민준은 주말에 보통 친구를 만나거나 영화를 본다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Minjun usually meets a friend or watches a movie on weekends.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A connective ending used when even if one out of many things happens, it does not have any relation to the following statement.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 막내는 비가 오거나 눈이 오거나 늘 밖에 나가 논다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Whether it's raining or snowing, the youngest always goes out to play.

grammar.gramInDepth1: (informal addressee-lowering) A sentence-final ending used when the speaker confirms and asks questions about a fact that he or she heard.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 자네 아들이 전교에서 제일 똑똑하다면서?
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I heard your son is the smartest in the whole school
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to ask if the current situation is different from what the listener or another person said before.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 맛없다면서 뭘 그렇게 많이 먹니?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: You said it wasn't good, but why are you eating so much?

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when having a doubt about a certain assumption and relating that to the fact or judgment of the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 졸업 후에 무슨 일을 해야 할지 모르겠다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I don't know what to do after graduation.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 가뭄이 계속 되는데 언제 비가 올지 걱정이다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The drought is continuing and I'm worried about when it will rain.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that something is the same as the present act or state mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 여러분, 제가 발음하는 대로 잘 따라 해 보세요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Everyone, follow my pronunciation.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 미술 작품은 네가 보고 느끼는 대로 감상하는 것이 중요해.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: It is important to appreciate art works as you see and feel them.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to imply that as the extent of the preceding statement becomes larger, that of the following statement also changes accordingly.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 보석은 크면 클수록 값이 비싸다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: The bigger the jewel, the more expensive it is.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 친하고 가까운 사이일수록 서로 예의를 잘 지켜야 한다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The closer you are to each other, the more polite you should be.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An ending of a word referring to a future event or assumption.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 군대 간 아들이 많이 씩씩해졌겠다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Your son must have gotten a lot stronger in the army.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An ending of a word referring to a possibility or ability.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 이 정도로 공부했으면 시험에 합격하겠지?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: If I studied this much, I would pass the test, right?

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the act denoted in the preceding statement has finished.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 봄이라 그런지 밥만 먹고 나면 잠이 쏟아졌다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Maybe because it was spring, I fell asleep after eating.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 숙제는 다 하고 나서 놀아라.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Play after you finish your homework.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to state that the speaker did the act mentioned in the preceding statement, then realized the fact in the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 차가 막혀 도착하고 보니 벌써 약속 시간이 지난 후였다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: When I arrived due to traffic jam, it was already past the appointment time.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 영어는 알고 보면 별것 아닌데 왠지 어렵게 느껴진다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: English is not a big deal, but somehow it feels difficult.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to state that the act mentioned in the preceding statement is continued.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 사진 속에서 우리 가족은 환하게 웃고 있었다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: My family was smiling brightly in the picture.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 벌써 아침 아홉 시가 넘었는데 승규는 아직도 자고 있다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: It's already past nine in the morning, and Seung-gyu is still sleeping.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that a certain act or state has been added to its preceding act or state, making it worse or better.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 우리 엄마가 직접 만들어 주시는 간식은 맛있는 데다가 영양도 풍부하다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: My mom's own snacks are delicious and nutritious.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 아버지는 담배를 피우시는 데다가 술도 자주 드셔서 건강이 나빠지셨다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: My father was in bad health because he smoked and drank a lot.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate the time, for which the act or state mentioned in the preceding statement lasts.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 내가 책을 읽는 동안 엄마는 뜨개질을 하셨다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: My mom knitted while I was reading a book.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 우리는 서울에 머무르는 동안 여러 관광지를 돌아보았다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: We looked around various tourist attractions during our stay in Seoul.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that an act or state mentioned in the preceding statement is the cause or reason for the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 길이 너무 막히는 바람에 늦었어요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I was late because of the traffic jam.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 비가 오는 바람에 소풍을 못 가게 되었다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The rain prevented me from going on a picnic.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that something has a certain tendency or is classified as such, instead of being sure of it.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 유민이는 외국인 친구와 자주 영어로 이야기해서 그런지 영어를 잘하는 편이에요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Yumin speaks English well because she often speaks English with foreign friends.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 승규는 책을 읽는 것을 좋아해서 주말마다 거의 도서관에 가는 편이다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Seunggyu likes to read books, so he goes to the library almost every weekend.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when an action or state, etc., is stopped and changed to another action or state.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 우리는 밥을 먹다가 차를 마셨다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: We ate and then we drank tea.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 유민이가 여행을 갔다가 돌아왔다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Yumin went on a trip and came back.

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to recall a past incident or state, and indicate that activity related to the incident or state has been suspended, and remains incomplete.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 내가 졸업하였던 고등학교가 바로 여기야.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: This is the high school I graduated from.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 네가 먹었던 음식은 유통 기한이 지난 건데?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The food you ate is past its expiration date

grammar.gramInDepth1: (informal addressee-raising) An expression used to tell a certain past incident with wonder, expecting a response from the listener.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 그곳에는 맛있는 음식들이 많던데요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: There are many delicious foods there.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to convey the speaker's past personal experience, expecting a response from the listener.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 우유는 약이랑 같이 먹으면 안 좋다고 하던데요.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I heard that milk is not good with medicine.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when the preceding statement is the purpose, result, method, amount, etc., of something mentioned in the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 길이 미끄러우니까 넘어지지 않도록 조심하세요.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: The road is slippery, so be careful not to fall.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 나는 코미디 영화를 보고 허리가 아프도록 웃었다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I laughed my back out at the comedy movie.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when a certain fact or situation happened after a fact or situation in the past.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 밥을 많이 먹었더니 배가 부르다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I'm full because I ate a lot.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A connective ending used when there is a new fact different from what one realized from an experience in the past.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 아침에는 눈이 오더니 지금은 하늘이 맑네.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: It snowed in the morning and now the sky is clear.
